question.title: Second-level Hibernate cache doesn't prevent query for @OneToOne relation

While User and its collections seem to be cached, Account, for some reason, is still not. So any time I need to repeatedly fetch a user

import com.example.pixel_user_api.data.entity.User;

@RepositoryDefinition(domainClass = User.class, idClass = Long.class)

    Optional<User> findById(Long id);

this happens:

Hibernate: select a1_0.id,a1_0.balance,u1_0.id,u1_0.date_of_birth,u1_0.name,u1_0.password,ed1_0.user_id,ed1_0.id,ed1_0.email from account a1_0 left join "user" u1_0 on u1_0.id=a1_0.user_id left join email_data ed1_0 on u1_0.id=ed1_0.user_id where a1_0.user_id=?

With second-level cache disabled, in the same scenario, my logs look like this:

Hibernate: select u1_0.id,a1_0.id,a1_0.balance,u1_0.date_of_birth,u1_0.name,u1_0.password,ed1_0.user_id,ed1_0.id,ed1_0.email from "user" u1_0 left join account a1_0 on u1_0.id=a1_0.user_id left join email_data ed1_0 on u1_0.id=ed1_0.user_id where u1_0.id=?
Hibernate: select pd1_0.user_id,pd1_0.id,pd1_0.phone from phone_data pd1_0 where pd1_0.user_id=?

The question is, assuming that Account log actually implies a DB hit, why is it being executed, bypassing my cache? How do I avoid it?

answers.body:
When using Hibernate's second-level cache with @OneToOne relationships, the default fetch type is EAGER, meaning it loads the associated entity right away. This can skip the cache and hit the database more than necessary.

To fix that, just switch to lazy loading for the @OneToOne relationship like this:

@OneToOne(mappedBy = "user", fetch = FetchType.LAZY)
@Cache(usage = CacheConcurrencyStrategy.READ_WRITE)
private Account account;

This way, Hibernate will only load the Account when you actually access it, and if it’s cached, it’ll pull from there instead of hitting the DB.

Note: Lazy loading can throw a LazyInitializationException if you try to access the Account (or any other table with lazy loading)after the session is closed. So, handle it carefully!

If you need eager fetching, you can use JOIN FETCH or @EntityGraph to manage the fetch strategy and keep the cache working.
